did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Wilton Historical Society Wilton Historical Information Collection

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Wilton History Room, Wilton Historical Society

did.abstract: The Wilton Historical Society Wilton Historical Information Collection contains newspaper clippings and magazine articles, as well as correspondence and other original documentation that goes beyond individual or family interest to relate directly to the broader history of Wilton. The collection also houses the papers, newsletters, and minutes of select local organizations. The bulk of the collection is from the late nineteenth century through the mid-twentieth century.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Wilton History Room, Wilton Historical Society.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], [Box no.], Wilton History Room, Wilton Historical Society

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Wilton Historical Society Wilton Historical Information Collection was compiled by the Wilton Historical Society.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: 1. Wilton Historical Society Wilton Historical Information Collection

The Wilton Historical Society, founded in 1938, collected extensive materials pertaining to Wilton history. Additions have been made by Carol Russell, Wilton Historical Society Archivist and Wilton Town Historian. The majority of the material included was created by historically significant local organizations and Wilton residents, and by contributors to various periodicals and newspapers.

The Wilton History Room is a unique collaboration between the Wilton Historical Society (WHS) and the Wilton Library Association (WLA). Compiled beginning in 1938, the archival collections of the Wilton Historical Society had been stored in the 18th century Fitch House. In 1980, the officers and trustees of the WHS, in conversation with the director and board members of the WLA, determined that a climate controlled space, improved organization, and better public accessibility were necessary; and so in January 1984 they established a home for the collection in the Wilton Library. Organization of the collections was supported by the Cudlipp Memorial Fund and undertaken by Carol Russell. The Wilton Historical Society has retained its ownership, while the Wilton Library maintains the collections, and provides access and assistance to patrons.

The Wilton History Room is one of the most complete, organized, and well-staffed historical research facilities, for a town of our size, in Fairfield County. It is financed by the WLA, The Russell Fund, and The History Room Fund.

Today, the original archival collections of the WHS take up half of the Wilton History Room. Another quarter are library items. The collected papers of local organizations comprise the remainder: Cannon Grange, Children's Theater, Daughters of the American Revolution, Hurlbutt Street School House Association, Kiwanis Club, League of Women Voters, Rotary Club, Town Association, Weir Farm Stewardship Committee, Wilton Garden Club, Wilton Land Conservation Trust, Wilton Library, Wilton Playshop, Wilton Woman's Club, and more.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Wilton Historical Information Collection is in large part a historiographical collection: taken as a whole, it represents how Wiltonians have told their stories, and what individuals, events, businesses, places, practices, and institutions have become central to our production of local history. Contents include local histories and profiles of prominent local residents as told in newspapers and periodicals, as narrated by local historians and displayed by the Wilton Historical Society and Museum, as celebrated during Bicentennial and other commemorative events, and as followed, forsaken, or reformed in the plans that Wilton clubs, organizations, and local governing bodies have made, the reports they have produced, and the changes they have introduced.

This collection houses much of the Wilton History Room's mid- to late-twentieth century content. The frequency and number of new accessions, and the collection contents' relevance to most Wilton research questions--excepting genealogy and local houses--makes this one of our most active collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The bulk of the Wilton Historical Information Collection is arranged by topic. The Lambert Collection forms its own series within WHI, with subdivisions for business, family, house and property, and miscellaneous topics. The remainder of the collection is organized by family name, with subdivisions for artists, architects, authors, musicians, local personalities, photographers, and miscellaneous others.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers should also consult the Wilton History Room's book collection, and cross-reference their topics in the Wilton History Room's other major collections as appropriate, particularly Maps and Printed Matter. Additional complementary items may be found in Oral Histories, Microfilms, DVDs, and the Pamphlet Collection. Researchers interested in early division of Wilton lands and the Norwalk Land Records will find the Card File helpful in locating mentions of specific family names.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Extensive information and exhibits regarding Wilton history, including artifacts and select documentation, are in the Wilton Historical Society Museum.
